article.description:
Jermareo Davidson had 16 points and 11
rebounds to lead No. 8 Alabama to a 74-44 victory over Texas
Southern on Saturday night.
article.headline: Steele sits, but No. 9 Alabama routs Texas Southern
article.linkText: Steele sits, but No. 9 Alabama routs Texas Southern
article.story: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. (AP) -- Jermareo Davidson didn't let Alabama (No. 9 ESPN/USA Today; No. 8 AP) stumble without star point guard Ronald Steele. Davidson had 16 points, 11 rebounds, eight blocked shots and three steals to lead the short-handed Crimson Tide to a 74-44 victory over Texas Southern on Saturday night. The Tide (5-0) played without Steele, a preseason All-America point guard who sat out the game to rest a sore knee. Coach Mark Gottfried said the move was "more precautionary than anything else." "I don't think that it's anything serious at all," Gottfried said. The big men dominated in his absence against the Tigers (1-4). Richard Hendrix added 15 points and 12 rebounds for the Tide, coming off a championship at the Paradise Jam in the Virgin Islands. Mykal Riley scored 12 points and shared time at the point with Brandon Hollinger. "Ron is such a great player. He brings so much to the team," Hendrix said. "With his shooting ability and his passing ability, we have such a great feel when we're playing with him. It was a little adjustment, but Brandon and Mykal stepped in and played well tonight." So did Davidson, who set a career high for blocks. His inside presence was a big reason why Texas Southern shot only 29 percent from the floor. "What I liked more than his numbers was without Ron in the game he stepped up his leadership," Gottfried said. Sollie Norwood led the Tigers with 16 points. Jacques Jones added 10 points and 10 rebounds. Texas Southern shot 29 percent and couldn't grab nearly enough rebounds to overcome the poor shooting. Alabama dominated the boards 60-35. "Alabama's pretty much what we thought they were," Tigers coach Ronnie Courtney said. "They're a big, athletic group of guys that can shoot and rebound the ball. They did everything well." Well, not everything. Without Steele running the offense, the Tide shot 39 percent, made 5-of-24 3-point attempts and had as many turnovers (14) as assists. The Tide had played three games in four days at the Paradise Jam, prompting Gottfried to give Steele a break. "It took everybody to fill in and step up," Davidson said. Alabama scored the game's first 10 points, leading by as many as 20 points in the half. Norwood scored the final five points to make it 38-23 at halftime, but Alabama opened the second half with a 12-2 run and coasted to the win.

statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
